newsitem.title: USA: Startup firm taps wallets of high-tech executives.
newsitem.headline: Startup firm taps wallets of high-tech executives.

text.p: Crossroads Software, a Silicon Valley startup, recently raised funds by tapping the wallets of executives of some key customers -- and their rivals, as well.

Founded a year ago, Crossroads aims to build products that will link huge business application software programs from different vendors by creating reusable "bridges" that can be used to integrate incompatible systems.

CrossRoads chief executive Katrina Garnett said the company recently raised $12.6 million from a financing round which included three corporate investors and 50 influential individuals, half of whom are top high-tech executives.

The carefully choreographed team of investors includes manufacturing and financial software giant SAP AG -- a leader in the industry around whose products many companies have rebuilt their entire businesses - and the services and consulting firm Ernst & Young LLP.

But the investor pool also includes a Who's Who of the software business applications universe, including PeopleSoft CEO Dave Duffield, Vantive Corp CEO John Luongo, Scopus Technology CEO Ori Sasson, and Clarify CEO Dave Stamm.
CrossRoads plans to tie together products of these companies through a combination of application-independent modules and connectors which work with specific programs.
Already the company has lined up strategic alliances with those companies and with Baan. It expects to offer "out-of-the-box" products to support their software.
Garnett, a veteran of Oracle Corp and Sybase, said that by drawing investors from among its partners, CrossRoads has created an additional barrier to entry to other potential competitors.

"Basically, I targeted the companies that are my partners, to build a real defense (against new entrants) - the presidents and CEOs, the COOs, the vice chairman and VPs of sales of all my partner companies," she said.
Garnett said such investors can be more purposeful allies than the so-called "angel" investors, friends and family of entrepreneurs who often help with startup capital.
"They need this solution to make their own businesses successful," said Garnett. "They're in a position every single day of their jobs to say something great, or to facilitate the relationship."

Furthermore, the investor pool brings together some ardent adversaries behind one company. "They're out there just as eager to share the risk with all their other competitors to make sure we're successful," she said.

Some Silicon Valley venture investors said the structure may make it more difficult for others to enter the business, but may also create a potential for conflicts of interest in their own business down the road.
Others, including Terence Garnett, husband of CrossRoads's and a venture partner at Venrock Associates, believe it could be a model for other startups, however.
The Garnetts provided initial capital for the venture, and Venrock, the Rockefeller family's venture capital group, participated in the recent funding.

The annual worldwide market for packaged software -- used in tasks ranging from running corporate resources, to manufacturing and procurement, to tracking employee records -- is estimated at $27 billion, or $44 billion including computer hardware.
